intro: Allium oleraceum var. complanatum, commonly known as flat-leaved garlic or broad-leaved leek, is a perennial herb native to Central Asia and parts of Europe. It belongs to the Amaryllidaceae family and is characterized by its flat, broad leaves and small, white or pale purple flowers. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm and is often found in grassy areas and along roadsides. Its bulbous roots are edible and have a mild garlic flavor, making it a useful plant in some traditional cuisines. It is also valued for its ornamental qualities and is sometimes cultivated in gardens.
